I had the pleasure of visiting this find establishment this past Sunday for brunch.

The wait staff were phenomenal. Food was excellent. The biscuits and gravy were quite possibly the best i've ever had.

Portion size was great. Leaving me enough to even bring home for a snack later.

Well worth the trip. First of many to come!

Hubby and I went here last night, because I saw a shrimp po'boy that was in New Orleans on t.v. and had to have one. So I turned to Yelp to find the best options for a Po'boy.  Well Boudreaux was close to the house, so we decided to go there. When we arrived, we stood at the front desk for about 5 minutes before we were sat. There as only two people that was working the floor that night, the bartender and the server. There was about four or five tables including a party of 8-10, so I think that there should have been at least another server on the floor. 

So was in a hurry and very distant, which did not bother us much since he did provide great service and besides we were ready to eat anyway without all of the extra details. Of course I ordered the Shrimp Po'Boy and my hubby ordered the Blackened Bleu Burger. After ordering, it was about 15 minutes when we received our food.

First everything came out great and looked good, but my shrimp was sat on top of my po'boy, just waiting to fall off. I hate having to maneuver my food to my mouth. Three of the shrimp fell off onto the table, which I still ate and gave my hubby a chance to steal one, I just wished that they would have constructed the sandwich a bit better. Also a little spice would have been great . The fries was fantastic!! My hubby burger was good too, and the pasta salad was just meh, nothing special.

Overall the food was good, but nothing that transferred us to New Orleans.
I've had brunch here a couple of times and I love it. If you're like me, you'll wanna come on a week day when it's a little slower. Try the gator bites!
If you're in the mood for an authentic Hurricane go here.  Dinner of blackened catfish hit the spot. Cornbread was average.  Great meal, and cool drinks!  What more do you want.
The jambalaya is incredible. Very good taste, not very spicy if that is your thing you can kick it up with hot sauce. Good local beer on tap and a friendly staff.

Jambalaya.  Oh my goodness.  The jambalaya.

I had to make myself stop eating.  I ate my left overs at 11am the next day, I was so excited about it.  

This is a really great little casual place.  I don't know why I never came in sooner.  I came here for date night last week and it was really nice.  Our server was on top of things, super helpful and constantly refilling water.  (Sometimes, I drink water like a mad woman).  The jambalaya has a little bit of everything in it; chicken, sausage, shrimp, craw fish.  It's amazing.  It's one of the pricier things on the menu, but a million times worth it.  

I need to come back here for the hurricanes.  An entire menu devoted to them?  Yes please.  I'll update my review after that!  

See you soon, Boudreaux's.

A definite favorite. Start off with a couple Vieux Carres (very much like a Manhattan). Excellent pour. 

Just love the etouffee - loaded with crawfish and a huge portion to boot!  Very casual and warm kind of place. Friendly service as contrasted by the rude service at the Crepe Cellar just down the street. 

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.

I was taken here for dinner and was simply amazed. My dinner began with a creamy asparagus soup that was awesome with a  side of corn bread. The corn bread wasn't impressive but the soup was. My entree was the vegetable rotini dish and it was amazing! It had multicolored rotini pasta with sun dried tomatoes, mushrooms, asparagus, etc. all topped off with a dash of asiago cheese. I liked that the dish did not include a lot of cheese and it came with a side of rosemary bread. Our server was great and the atmosphere is nice and cozy!!!

Me and one of my friends visited Boudreaux's last month after an evening yoga class in the neighborhood.  It was a rainy, cold Thursday evening, so the place wasn't busy.  Unfortunately, we were immediately struck by the VERY THICK haze and stench of cigarette smoke.  

My friend ordered the black-bean veggie burger with a side of potato salad and I ordered the shrimp po'boy with a side of fries.  We were both shocked by the large portions of both of our meals.

The seasoning on my fries was a tad stronger than I like but not overwhelming.  The bread was lightly toasted and very thick which made eating the sandwich a little difficult.

However, my friend commented on the fact that her veggie burger had the texture and taste of a regular beef burger! Also, she noted that her potato salad was very satisfying and delicious.

Although our meals were very enjoyable, having to deal with the thick stench of smoke put a major damper on everything else. Also, our waitress didn't appear to be all that interested in providing much service to our table.  

I hear good things about their brunch menu, so I would be willing to try them again during the day. Hopefully, the next time I go it will be on a nice day so I can sit outside and not have to worry about cigarette smoke interfering with my meal.

Literally amazing. The service was great, the food came fast and the food was incredible. I ordered the shrimp and grits (a must-have) and my friend got the chicken and waffle sandwich which was also amazing. The beignets were hot and fresh and delicious. This place is better than most places actually located in Louisiana. Will definitely be back.

I went here for the first time and loved it! I ordered the shrimp and grits and it was really good. Also GREAT service! Ebony was our waitress and she was very friendly, attentive, and helpful with the menu! I would definitely come back for round 2.
AmaZing flavorful food in a colorful atmosphere. Will definitely come again and again.

As a neighborhood spot...I have tried and tried and tried to find something I like here.I have just never experienced a dish that I found to be tasty or worth the money. I don't remember having exceptional service there either. Is been awhile since I've gone, that I honestly don't remember much else. Clearly it was so lackluster that I haven't even tried to go back since. Unfortunately its not one of the places in the neighborhood I recommend. Sorry...just the truth. /

I really wish I liked seafood because much of the Cajun menu at Boudreaux's involves seafood and my boyfriend loves the place. Plus, with Mellow Mushroom gone, there just aren't all that many restaurants in NoDa anymore. Still, Boudreaux's is really good. I often get the blackened burger with blue cheese. It's pretty delicious though the very onion-y bun is kind of overwhelming. The New Orleans/Mardi Gras-themed restaurant is a fun place with a good vibe. They also serve up a good brunch menu.

Lover of Cajun food, I had to come here. I love the rustic interior inside. Service was pretty great as well, our server was so friendly & welcoming! The food was kinda of a letdown though which is SOO disappointing because I had really high hopes due to all the great reviews. The food wasn't bad but it was just mediocre. Also the cornbread was cold & dry which makes me super sad because I loveeee cornbread. We really enjoyed the crab/corn hush puppies but the shrimp po boy & etoufee was just alright! (Needs more seasoning)

Great food for the money. I had the fried chicken served over white rice and gumbo. It was quite tasty and for under $12 quite reasonable as well. 

The outside looked very eclectic and the inside used bright colors and cool paintings. 

There were two hiccups that prevented a five stars. Our server was very polite but felt like she was new. She didn't really explain the menu and she didn't check back with us often. The second reason was the price of the appetizer.  I had the hush puppies.  They charged $7 for four. Granted they were made from crab cakes but $7 for four small balls of fried hush puppies were a but too expensive.

Great food.  The service was wonderful. My mom says that her stomach gives it a A+. Mom had the gumbo- delicious.  I had the biscuits with gravy-ambrosia in my mouth.   The only sad is that there isn't a parking lot or I may not have seen it, but I parked around the corner.

A nice French environment (washed out walls with wooden furniture and scattered plants). The workers make you feel at home with their rolled up flannel shirts and comfortable jeans attire I got the croissant Benedict with a side of French fries (which were to die for!!) we also ordered the shrimp and grits; it had a strong flavor so prepare yourself!

I really give it 3.5 stars.  I got the sampler platter.  The gumbo and jambalaya were good.  The red beans and rice was just okay and lukewarm.  My daughter got fried chicken and subbed the sides for collard greens and mac-n-cheese.  She liked the chicken but not the sides.  We both liked the cornbread.  The service was just okay.

Didn't really know what to expect for my first visit but the service was good and the food was great. We went for brunch on Sunday specifically for the beignets which were a bit disappointing. I don't understand what's all the rage? HOWEVER, the gator bites are a must have. We've gotten 2 plates each time we've been there for dinner. The étouffée is also a good option. A bit spicy.

So driving around, lost in a new city, we fell upon this place! Not busy at all around 1pm in the afternoon on a Tuesday, but the music was pleasant and Cajun food, always a must! The place was very clean and service was genuine. Our server gave us some great recommendations and even gave us some idea of the area and even days where they had specials per our taste. 

The menu for alcohol was pretty cool. They had a section for category 1-5 hurricane drinks, which our server also said was half off till a certain time. Caught my attention. It had different descriptions for category 1-5 rum drinks which varied on strength and liquors. I got the cat 2 because that was the strength of hurricane Matthew when it hit us in charleston just the week before. It also had info on around 5 hurricanes that hit Louisiana  in the past and had names specifically for those and personalized concoctions for those hurricane drinks. I've never seen this on a drink menu, I really enjoyed it, went along with the theme of Louisiana!

For the food! We only got appetizers because we stopped in between house hunting. We got the BBQ shrimp and the bacon jack fritters. When I read BBQ shrimp, I automatically think of BBQ, southern BBQ, sweet with a little spice, but this was something completely different. In a great way. A buttery Cajun spice mix, not spicy, but flavorful, and the shrimp were a decent size as well for an appetizer. The bacon jack fritters were a surprise as well. They seemed to be fried but not greasy at all, which I always worry about with fried appetizers. You get around 5 pieces and the sauce is what really gets your attention. I'd eat that with any type of appetizer, Parmesan cream sauce. Yummy yummy. 

We definitely will be back to try out the dinner options and enjoy some of the nightlife!

I've had a few great dinners here, but my favorite was a night out with one of my best girlfriends when she was visiting. We rode around a bit uptown looking for something good, and then we headed out to NoDa when we exhausted our options. 

I had the Vegeletta sandwich, and she had the blackened catfish. The food was great. Our server was funny, but he also left us alone when he saw that we were having a good time. We had my laptop with me, and we jumped on the Smelly Cat's internet connect and watched R. Kelly's "Real Talk" video on Youtube. We were sitting near the window out front, so we could watch the crowd pass by. We giggled and ate, and it was awesome.
Atmosphere isn't anything special but the food is very good. I recommend the fish and grits and the jambalaya.

Words don't describe the taste of the food... everything I are was beyond delicious... flavorful... mouthwatering...addictive.... awesome... the waiter was super nice, friendly staff, I'm going back... This place is 10 star

People were right when they recommended Boudreaux's shrimp and grits.  It's among the best I've had in Charlotte.  It always taste better with cheesy grits!  The andouille sausage was flavorful and the shrimp was good.  My boyfriend had the Monte Christo and I really liked it.  It even came with two slices of pineapple . The rest of the brunch menu looks good as well so I would love to come back to give some other items a try!

Eh - where's the flavor?

We walked in here pretty early on a Saturday - roughly 5:30ish. The place was pretty empty but as we were seated all the of the sudden the room filled up. There was one waiter for a long time and then finally a second waiter showed up. The service (although super busy) was very friendly and efficient. 

We ordered the crab bruschetta, the jerk chicken sandwich, and the mahi mahi mulate. While the prices are fair (pretty cheap actually) the food is exactly what you pay for. The crab bruschetta thing was ok - no flavor and the texture reminded me of something from a can. The jerk chicken sandwich was blah - I literally just ate the chicken (which had NO spice or flavor...I thought this was a JERK chicken sandwich??) as the bread was too hard to bite into (stale?). The Mulate was pretty good - the etouffe was good but nothing memorable. The best part was probably the fries that came with the sandwich. 

Overall - blah blah blah. Nothing was awful but nothing was good enough to make me come back.

My days of the week include Bloody Mary Sundays and this is my favorite place to cure what ails me. If you want/need/crave a bloody mary, come here. Bloody Mary bars are wonderful because I can and will make a killer bloody mary when supplied with the right ingredients. They have several vodkas to choose from including a pepper vodka which is great for lovers of spice. There are probably 8 different bloody mixes to choose from, including a great house mix. There are hot sauces galore! And so many pickled vegetables to throw in, not just olives. The best thing is they'll have your vodka ready so once that clock hits noon, it's on. 

The food at brunch (because I've only eaten here during brunch - prime bloody mary hour) is aiite. Standard omelettes and other things covered in hollandaise sauce. Have yet to try their beignets, but have heard great things about them. 

In short - when it's bloody mary time, Boudreaux's is my number one.
Decided to stop in after reading all of the wonderful reviews was extremely disappointed the meal was so awful I didn't even attempt to finish it money wasted!!
Cajun Mary - make your own Bloody Mary bar!  Hot!  Seafood Gumbo - best I've had outside of Nawlins. Jacob - world's most enthusiastic waiter. Great place for a lazy Saturday afternoon brunch.

Boudreaux's Louisiana Kitchen was the first place my coworker and I went to in Charlotte.  Mostly because I was craving Shrimp and Grits!  It's been a while since I had some Southern food.  Overall, based on the dish, pretty good.

We stopped in at 6:12pm. We were seated immediately, and then waited until 6:35 for someone to at least offer us water or drinks. The server attended to the one other table on the patio, but ignored us. The last straw was when another couple was seated, he immediately went to take their drink order. I'd like to comment in the food, but I was never asked to place an order!

The Cajun festival turned out to be a big flop, and wasn't really a festival and the only Cajun food they had was some overpriced gumbo that tasted like ass and was covered in flies, not to mention the staff didn't even lift an eye when we thanked them.

So here we are, at Bourdraoooow's in NODA!

Service is sloooooow. It wasn't even that busy. The food was okay though. We went with basic breakfast foods, fries and cheese grits (really rich). My grand-pappy used to make cheese grits with shrimp and andewy sausage, so I didn't really think much of the grits here. Everything else was standard.

Slooooooooow service.

I've absolutely loved every dish I've had here. I highly recommend this place to get your Cajun fix. Love their location. Be aware, at Sunday brunches, it tends to get very busy and the service gets a little weakened. 
Order the shrimp and crawfish étouffée :)

I went with some friends this past Saturday and was pleasantly surprised! The food was amazing! I lived in New Orleans and haven't found a gumbo that could compare. I had a few bites of my friends and it was out of this world! I ordered the sea bass special and when I asked for a side of sauteed spinach, our server was happy to ask if the kitchen could do it. They, of course, could! Our server was super fun and Quick!!! My friend said the hurricanes were pretty awesome! If you go check out the hurricane menu. I can't wait to go back!

Excellently prepared Cajun food set in a laid back atmosphere.   I love this place because it's quieter and less crowded than most of the nearby restaurants, but doesn't skimp on the freshness and quality of the meal.   Don't fool around and go straight for the bourbon fried chicken.

Pretty good food with a Cajun flair.
I think of Boudreaux's as Cajun Lite, because let's face it, they're not authentic Bayou. 
Slow service. Always. Expect it. Plan on it. Don't let it harsh your buzz. 

The food here can range from good to really outstanding on any given day. 

I usually found the waiters to be as friendly as their limited time permitted.
 
I ate at Boudreaux's about once every two weeks. 
The wait staff remembered that I drank sweet tea!

Service is not bad, it's just not very fast. The problem is that many times during lunch, there is only one person waiting on everyone. My schedule was always flexible, so getting back on time from lunch was not a problem. For those on a tight schedule, having lunch here and getting back to the office on time, could easily be a tricky proposition. Fast food - this is NOT.

My favorite lunch entrees were the Cajun meat loaf, and their smothered pork chop. 
I liked the collards and mac 'n cheese for side dishes. 

I ate at shrimp po boy ONCE, and it was mostly lettuce. I did not order this again. 

I love the funky décor, the relaxed atmosphere, and their central NODA location. I was usually able to park right on the street next to the restaurant. 

Prices are reasonable for the quality of their food. 

When I wanted something really good for lunch, this was my destination. This is one of the places in Charlotte that I really miss.

First time here and I'll definitely be back. Came here for a late lunch on Saturday so we were the only ones in the restaurant. The server was friendly and attentive. We ordered the crawfish & spinach dip, fried chicken with jambalaya, and shrimp & grits. Everything came out hot and it was delicious! They could've added more crawfish meat to the spinach dip though. Nonetheless, the food was flavorful and portions were big. Both entrees came with corn bread which wasn't all that great. It was dry and tasteless so I could've done without it. We sat by the opened garage/patio area which added an awesome ambiance to the place.

I love spicy Cajun food.  I love NoDa, so I desperately want to love Boudreaux, but every time I go is a disappointment.  I hadn't been there is over a year and decided to go for brunch.  The big draw, besides location, is the well appointed Bloody Mary bar they set up for Sunday brunch.  Other than that, I won't be back.  The food is bland, nothing Cajun or Creole about it, except  the names of the dishes.  I started with the Gumbo Ya Ya.  Its consistency and taste was that of wallpaper paste.  For brunch I got the special of the day- strawberry cream cheese stuffed French Toast and cheese grits for my side. ( I would have prefered bacon or sausage as a side, but was told they didn't have either meat as side offerings-really ? breakfast without bacon or sausage??) When I got my entree, the grits were touching the french toast, and the strawberry "compote" over the french toast was also in the cheese grits.  Sloppy.  I scrapped the grits off the main plate in order to save my meal.  The french toast was dry, and has cream cheese inside, with canned strawberries. The Strawberry compote on top of the french toast was also straight from a can.  C'mon guys, its summer- this was supposed to be the "special", yet there was nothing special about.  Again, bland and disappointing.  The cheese grits I managed to salvage that didn't have canned sugared strawberry sauce in it were the standout of the meal, and that's high praise from someone who isn't a big grit fan.

UPDATE: Another testament to Alex and his charismatic personality. As my group was walking by Boudreaux's for lunch this afternoon, Alex came out the door to say hi to us and tell us it was good to see us. I will absolutely be back and looking for him!

 I've read a lot of the reviews and I feel terrible because I have to disagree. We were only perusing the outdoor menu when a waiter appeared in the window in front of us, opened the door, and informed us that they were having $2.50 mimosas and half off Bloody Mary's. That sold our group of 5. We were seated immediately by Alex and I have to tell you, he was so personable, he's the main reason (tied with taste of food) I'm writing this review. 

Alex immediately took our drink order and recommended appetizers. We ordered mimosas, gator bites, bacon fritters, she-crab soup and corn and crab hush puppies. The gator bites were smaller and there were only 4 hush puppies but none of the apps were lacking in flavor! They were SO delicious and we're shared among 5 people amicably. 

As far as entrées go, we ordered jambalaya, etouffe, red beans & rice, shrimp & grits, and muffaletto. They were all spot on and hit every spot we could have imagined. 

My favorite part of our hour and a half dinner was our waiter Alex. He should be requested every single time you come in! Thanks for such a great experience!

Okay - confession #1) the waitress from Davidson Street Public House said if you're going there next, order the Red Beans and Rice with Andouille Sausage. Confession #2) we peeked in and there was no one in Boudreaux's at the time - it was bright, empty and I didn't want to feel like I was on display in a fishbowl, so we ordered and had the food delivered to Sanctuary. Holy Yapple Dapple Yabba Freakin' Doo! Tasted like they have been stewing/cooking those beans all day long - jam packed with flavor and spices. Nice consistency to the rice (not overcooked). Let's not forget the sausage - nice portion with just a little heat. Great choice of eats for a pub crawl or foodie crawl. If I remember correctly too, it was under ten bucks. Will definitely be back to try the Jambalaya that Kelly C raved about!

I'm surprised to be giving a four-star review! We hadn't been here in years and decided to give it a go. Service was very slow early on. Hushpuppy app was kind of sad. But then our server was able to get more focused, and then our meal came. Fish and grits...delish. My brother had the Red Beans & Rice and loved it. My husband's burger was great. So, despite a half empty restaurant on a Friday night and a slow start, our bellies and taste buds are very happy!

Delicious!! We went after church on a Sunday for brunch. Didn't have to wait to be seated but food did take a while to come out. But when it did come it was hot and fresh! Shrimp and grits are my favorite! I've be back! Good service!
There's live music, mimosa bar complete with fruit and berries, your choice of cranberry, pineapple, orange juice, or hurricane mix. $3.50 double mimosa price tag. Can't beat this with a stick!

Boudreaux's is a chain that has only one other location...in Blacksburg, Virginia, which is such a culinarily bereft location that for nearly six years, I went there quite a lot.  Among the faculty at Virginia Tech, Boudreaux's was known as "The Best Restaurant in Town".  And truly, a big bowl of their seafood gumbo at that location was a pretty satisfying thing, though nothing to write home about.  In Charlotte, though, they have a lot more competition.  I was in there recently and had corn chowder (thick and cheesy) and fried oysters (I know, right?) and rolled out feeling kind of bloated.  Anyway, my feelings about Boudreaux's are mixed, but they're pretty convenient if, say, you have to pick someone up at the train station and get them something halfway-decent to eat right away and it's after 9.

This was my second experience here and I thought a reservation and early arrival would help us out on the wait. However when we arrived at 730p we immediately ordered drinks while we became familiar with the menu. By 8p we ordered our appetizers due to chatting as girlfriends we hadn't seen each other in a while. Our appetizers came our fairly quick and we shared. My BBQ shrimp had a very funny and unfamiliar taste to it. The sauce even stated strange. By 8:30p we all were ready to order. It took exactly one hour and fifteen minutes for our food to come out. The manager brought it to us because we were beginning to have reservations and concern of the wait time. And they guest around us were getting their food sooner. 
I totally understood that this was a busy night for them and it was a Friday but 1 hour and 15minutes for your entree is a bit long. But everyone enjoyed their food, we took majority of it home with us as it had gotten really late to eat such heavy food my 9:45p

Came here for lunch looking for creole food after an appointment.  The restaurant is cute and in a cute part of town (NODA).  The waitstaff was really nice!  I ordered the etoufee and it was okay.  My parents live in New Orleans so I know good creole food when I taste it.  This was a good attempt but just missed the mark.  I would be willing to try it again but I wasn't impressed on the first go round.

First time here and I absolutely love this place, the food is extremely tasty. I had the the gator bites and the etouffee which tasted amazing you can get it in either a small plate or large. The restaurant was very spacious and had patio space for those who wanted to eat outside and enjoy the spring air. They also have a stance indoors where they open the doors to allow fresh air in. The atmosphere had a old southern feel, as if I was l eating righting in New Orleans. My waitress was very attentive, my pineapple mojito was delicious, it was the perfect balance of mint and fruit. I would totally recommend this place to anyone. Definitely

Worst service I've ever experienced at a restaurant. No one was at the door to greet us, then when someone did she didn't know where to seat us. Then it took 15 minutes to be greeted by our server and once we noticed he didn't have a uniform, we knew it was going to bad. We waited 45 minutes for our food just for the server to tell us he dropped it all. We wait another 25 minutes for our refire and it tasted rushed, just as we expected. I had the shrimp and grits and the grits were thick and clumpy and the whole dish was overseasoned. We waited 15 minutes to try to see a manager but none of the servers were in the dining room. Finally we go to the host stand to try to request the manager when the hostess tells us to have a nice day! We had barely touched our food and hadn't paid for anything but she wished us well on our way out! We looked around for our server but he and the hostess disappeared to the back. So we just left. After the horrendous service and difficult parking, I will not be back.

Thoroughly enjoyed my experience here. Our waiter Jacob was pleasant with a beautiful accent and disposition I might say. I had the crab cake croissant which was delicious. Although it was just one patty, it was flavorful and just enough for lunch. Lunch was accompanied by my Danny boy Hurricane. Gf had shrimp po boy and gave high praise. I was visiting from out of town for the first time and I appreciated this creole southern food that was both comforting and appetizing.

A friend was visiting from out of town and she wanted to visit the NoDa area. We went on the last day she was in town, which I did not realize majority of NoDa was pretty much a ghost town on a Monday afternoon. We found Boudreaux's by chance and decided to stop in. The food hit the spot for a southern girl. 

I had the bourbon fried chicken Meat&Three option  -the sauce was perfect and full of flavor. The Charleston cheddar grits hit the spot. And the collard greens were also bursting with flavor. The only complaint: the corn bread was a bit dry and not served with any butter. 

The service was great, attentive - should've been anyhow considering there were only 2 other tables. Our drinks never went dry. We left full and satisfied. Definitely worth the trip back to the NoDa area to try a few more dishes.

Been here several times and it has always been good food and good service. We often stop by before shows at the Neighborhood Theater. Tonight however is a different story. I have been sitting here for an hour and still don't have my food. Our show starts at 8 so we are leaving hungry as we never got our dinner.

Mimosa, gumbo and cornbread.

Mimosa--:-)

Gumbo--the meat was so lovely and tender, I ate it all first and then kind of looked and picked around my rice, wishing for more. 

Cornbread--the sweet kind. Actually could have used a bit of salt to enhance the flavor. I grew up having cast-iron skillet cornbread, dense and crusty and not a hint of sugar. Love sweet cornbread, but as a fan of kettle corn, my ideal now includes both tastes at once. 

The service was kind and leisurely. I was sad that the beignets are only on Saturday and Sunday...note that the mimosas are cheaper on Sunday.

This was my second time visiting this establishment, and was only 10% occupied. It's located in the NODA area and expected more occupants. I don't mind, but it would be nice to have a 65% full restaurant. They only have one TV, and partial outdoor seating. 

The waiter was friendly, we had the same waiter on both visits two weeks apart, and she remember us from before. 

The food is New Orleans style, and is served in large portions. 

This last visit i ordered the large crab cake salad with spinach, and it was delicious and healthy. 

My friend ordered the Mulatte and took home half the serving. We will return, maybe on a Friday or Saturday evening.
i'm mostly salty that beignets aren't served at night but also salty that some new orleans staples just don't fit the standards i have

this place was delicious!! It's in a really cute part of town near all the breweries with a ton of free street parking. We went on a Sunday and got $2.50 mimosas. The food was delicious- I got the breakfast burrito and my boyfriend got stuffed pancakes. The only reason this isn't 5 stars is because I was looking forward to some different Cajun options but there didn't seem to be a whole lot on the menu.

On July 4th, I was walking around NoDa, checking out some arts. I was hungry, I could eat a horse, so I stopped here put some yummy in my tummy! 

Good:
- Signature Jambalaya is the die for. Tip: Get the T'boo (small) size; it is a filling portion $10.00
I mean who says you need to drive to Bourbon Street for authentic Cajun dishes.
Eh ok:
- Not too exciting ambiance. But Great food. 
Boo:
- I think they overlooked that simple amenity that would keep our purses/coats from ending up on the floor. Hooks under bar, hello!
- Guest WiFi??!  I was connected to their WiFi, but couldn't browse.

I enjoyed my Jambalaya, so I'm sure I'll be back in the future.

Three and Half Yelps

I had this place catered where I work for lunch one day. I had the Chicken Carbonara and I thought it was really good. I haven't been inside their physical location so I can't really comment on the inside and the service.

The menu is so broad and delicious. As a pescatarian I found multiple menu items worth trying. The hush puppies are amazing and their catfish was cooked perfectly. I ate here once and decided it moved quickly up the list as one of my favorite CLT restaurants. It's a must-try if you enjoy Cajun food -- they do it right!

Took a walk in NoDa and ended up having a crazy experience at Boudreaux's. If by crazy, I mean I ordered their special Taco Loco for breakfast. This place is a gem and their food is amazing!! Braised beef, poached eggs is a crazy twist for brunch that goes down easy with my double mimosa!
Great food! Prices are very reasonable! Gumbo was good....Shrimp and Grits was amazing!

Above average service, but just so-so food when compared to my favorite Louisiana style meals at other restaurants around the country (including one across town in Charlotte several years back).  I was looking for great Louisiana food with much more mojo and passion to it, so it was definitely a let down visit for me.  Then again, the experience was interesting with the minimalistic dive bar type ambiance, and the food was at least ok even though too simple... Just not too much wow factor or loving soul in the dishes I received from the kitchen... 

It seems there are better places to go to get more satisfying meals for the money, but if you're in this exact area and really in the mood for Louisiana style food, maybe you'll be OK if you can manage your expectations...

i am mot a huge fan of Creole food but i really enjoy the flavor of the Shrimp poor boy sandwich. The only thing i was a little bummed about it the veins were in the shrimp which will cause me not to get that sandwich again. The  shrimp and grits look tasty so i will definitely try that the next time when i come.The little pastry that i got i think it was called bignet or something like that was amazing . i will go back again but for the main menu not brunch.

Gave this restaurant another try this week. Earlier this year was very disappointed in the slow service and lack of staff during a planned brunch with a large group. This restaurant redeemed themselves with very friendly staff and  service today. The tilapia was excellent as were the sides; green beans and sweet potato fries!  Their sauces and spices add such a southern and Cajun flare. The parking in NoDa is improving, so hopefully the restaurants will flourish even more!

Wasn't impressed. Good was just meh. Seafood gumbo had a weird taste. The crab and corn hush puppies were a disappointment. My niece  found a fly in the bottle of ketchup after she had put some on her food. They were good about it. Replaced her food and gave her a voucher for free entree or appetizer. Was in Charlotte for a family reunion. Was hungry and excited to find this place. Was just in NOLA in July. This doesn't compare.

Before Cabo Fish Taco expanded into more space... the wait used to be ridiculous.  What would normally happen was that we'd go to NoDa craving Cabo, but then end up at Boudreaux's.  The thought was that we could grab a hurricane and then come back when our table at Cabo was ready.  Needless-to-say we never made it to Cabo whenever we went to Boudreaux's.  

The ettoufee is my favorite here... great and unique spot for Charlotte.  Haven't gotten to try a lot of the menu items yet, but I will definitely be up to the challenge of getting to know all the items personally.

Usually for NoDa... end up parking on the street... it's worked out most of the time.  Gallery crawl nights make it more challenging, but still doable.

I've never really been a cajun fan because I don't like crawfish and I'm not really a fan of beans and rice (see my latin and asian reviews).  Thankfully my idea that all cajun food contains these is misguided.  

On my last visit to Boudreaux's with the dinner group, I had the Cajun Carbonara and the she crab soup.  The soup had a nice spice level to it as was as the pasta dish. The disappointment I had was that it looked like the pasta was the pre-cooked rotini version importanted from your favorite food service company.  But it was still good.

The service was good, the drinks tasted good and were not weak like some places make them.  Unfortunately, it was a lot of food where 1/2 of my meal went home in a box with me.  But it tasted good the next day also.

My only surprise was the restaurant wasn't busy.  When I called for a reservation at 7pm, they told me they had another big group coming in at that time and asked if we could go 15 before or after.   But when a friend and I arrived early for drinks, that group had the only tables (2-3) occupied in the place.  Oh well it was still good, we were still served and we still got out before that group.  I just found the request odd considering they weren't busy.

Went here with one or my buddies on a weekday lunch. The food was quite enjoyable. 

We started with the alligator bites, then had i had the jambalaya and my friend had ribs and fries. If you're a fan of Cajun food you'll like it here. It was very tasty.

Service was good, but since it was late in the afternoon, we were among only a few other people. I'd like to see the dining room and get a feel for the place when it's more crowded and lively.

Overall I'd like to give it a try again, but it's definitely a good spot for Cajun.
This was a delightful experience. The Bourbon chicken was excellent, the ya ya to die for. The flavors were amazing. The location is avant guard, you will love this place

You don't go here for dinner. You don't go for lunch. You sort of go for brunch.

You always go for the best Bloody Mary bar in Charlotte.

I am from Destrehan LA about 20 min from the French Quarter. I have been eating Gumbo all of my life. The Gumbo at Boudreaux's is the most Authentic Gumbo I have had in Charlotte. I have tried at least 5 other places on Yelp that serve Gumbo. I dislike CajunQueen because of the tomatoes. We never put a red base in our Gumbo, not that you shouldn't but, it doesn't taste like the Authentic Cajun Gumbo I was raised on. At Boudreaux's I always get some to, go to put in the freezer. LOL!

Spent the weekend in Charlotte and this was recommended by the hotel staff. EXCELLENT CHOICE! The jambalaya, fish, chicken, fried pickles, gator and burgers were all good. To top it off our server Alex was Awesome!

my husband and i went on our honeymoon to new orleans, so we are huge fans of cajun/creole cooking. our tastebuds were pleasantly tingled by their tasty morsels. i got a shrimp po' boy with their house potato salad, and the hubs got the jambalaya. both were excellently prepared and mouth-watering. i was super full halfway thru the meal, and i got to take a good portion of home--which was totally awesome. my kids thoroughly enjoyed the leftovers, which is saying a lot about the deliciousness of this place.

one note about this place: i guess the restaurant behind it is the same kitchen/same food. not sure if it's cheaper or nicer, but i am curious...

I went to Boudreax's for dinner, and the food was pretty good.  We started off with the fried oysters.  The breading was seasoned nicely, and the fried oysters were nice and crispy.  Inside, they weren't as juicy as oysters near the beach, but they were decent for being in Charlotte.  Overall, they were solid, but I've definitely had better. 

For my entree, I ordered the mulatte, which is shrimp and crawfish étouffée over blacked fish.  Étouffée is tough to cook well and having been to New Orleans, I've had the real stuff.  The étouffée here was pretty tasty  and held its own well.  There is some creole spice to the dish that gave it that Louisiana taste.  The sauce was good and made for a tasty dish. 

However, there weren't that many crawfish compared to the shrimp, and the shrimp were an average size.  Both didn't taste as fresh as they could've been, but the fish was the highlight of the dish.  I chose tilapia and it was seasoned and blackened exceptionally.  All the Cajun spices were sealed in the blackened crust, giving it some great flavor.  All this was served over rice with a pice of cornbread, making it a very filling meal. 

Overall, the food was good at Boudreax's, but not great.  My rating would really be 3.5 stars.  Fresher seafood would really enhance some of their dishes a lot, but for being in Charlotte, their food is worth try if you're craving some New Orleans inspired food.

It is a very relaxing place in the heart of Noda. 

I ordered the Veggie Benny which was good! Defiantly should try it for brunch!

Again, my Creole nose is tuned to the hunt to satisfy my craving for that perfect po'boy, that savory gumbo. Boudreaux was third on my list for my Cajun fancy, and I found myself there on Saturday night with a friend. There was about a 10 minute wait for a seat, which wasn't bad at all. 

An absolutely lovely first Bloody Mary experience. Though the presentation was nothing like what Yelp's gorgeous picture provides, it was still smooth, yet hot and spicy. Good stuff, I would get another.

There was a bit of an awkward moment. My Cajun unicorn is a fried oyster po'boy. Never managed to have one, and have always been denied at the last minute. This was no exception. 
Upon ordering, my waiter got a very sad, contemplative look on his face, informing me that due to the tragedy of the gulf oil spill, there were no more oysters. I stared at him incredulously, then slowly turned my eyes down to the Creative Loafing magazine I had open, to the page that advertised the largest oyster festival in the world that happened in Myrtle Beach that very day. Our eyes met and he had that panicked, feverish look that waitstaff sometimes get when they're fervently praying that you don't call them out on something.

So I didn't. I got a damn shrimp po'boy instead. [Miraculously, though the oysters were doomed, the shrimp managed to survive. Well... except for the ones on my sandwich.]

Incredulousness aside, the po'boy was pretty good. Huuuuuge roll, but it was soft, so there wasn't any bread stabbing painfully into my gums as I ate. Plenty of shrimp, so I guess my only lament would be that I wish the remoulade was tangier, or rather, tangy at all.
I got the potato salad as a side, which didn't disappoint. Sweeter than most potato salads, but great herb flavor and just the right amount of creamy.

My friend got the bourbon chicken, which she tells me would have been great if it wasn't so salty. It seemed to put her off her meal and she only managed to eat part of it.

All in all, I think I'd be back again to sample some gumbo when all is said and done. However, I need to tack off the rest of the restaurants on my Cajun bucket list'o Charlotte before I return here.
Great experience and food.  Truly delicious.  Staff was friendly & hard working.  Only good things to say and would definitely return.

I've got roots in Louisiana (but I don't hold 'LouisianaStyle" restaurants outside of Louisiana to the same standard)... That said... These ppl should be shut down for claiming to be a NOLA style restaurant. On top of that, the service left a lot to be desired. Not my favorite experience of the year.

Came into today just to get some beignets at around 5:30. First of all the restaurant was completely empty so that was probably a sign. After waiting five minutes at the hostess podium someone finally came over to seat us. Once seated we waited at the table for 15 mins for someone to come over and maybe get us a water for starters. But then decided to just get up and leave after seeing the staff drinking at the bar and no one came over.Never going back to actually try this place out and the staff was completely and utterly RUDE.

This place is FANTASTIC!  I ate here for Sunday brunch - the bloody mary bar was the best I have ever seen and 1/2 off for top shelf vodka (grey goose, ketel one, etc).  The mimosas are $2.50 and also absolutely delicious.  I ordered the muffaletta which was very good but the jambalaya...oh my goodness.  Please order the jambalaya!  I can't wait to go back and (1) drink more alcohol, and (2) try the gumbo.

I went the week after Christmas which is usually slow at most restaurants until NYE. So the restaurant was pretty empty however we didn't let it stop us. We had the crawfish dip appetizer and considering my boyfriend doesn't eat seafood normally and has been talking about it since we left I'd have to say it was a hit. We had for our entree's the veggie burger and the shrimp po boy. Both of which were good. I didn't like the fries with the po' boy but I'm very particular when it comes to fries so I don't take anything away from them for that. We went on a Tuesday when Hurricane's are half, we started with the category 2 and worked our way up to 4. We've said next time we will try a category 5. Overall it was great and we are looking forward to going back.

A comfortable environment, the prices are a bit high but it's worth it. I'd rate this place a 4.7 I got the Gator Bites as an appetizer and Etoufee for my entrée. If you like shrimp and crawfish I highly recommend this dish.

The WORST waitress I have ever encountered. The food was delicious, only reason I'm giving it 3 stars. The entire staff seemed preoccupied and not worried about our party at all. We were the only table in the entire restaurant and it seemed as if the staff was all too busy to attend to us. Good food, nice prices, horrible staff.

Soooo, came in last weekend after a few months and man have things changed! Idk if it's under new management, has new chefs, or what but the entire experience was nothing like it has been in the past. Should've known something was wrong when it was basically dead on a Saturday. The service was pretty good but the food was just blah. So blah. I ordered the etouffe over Charleston cheese grits instead of rice. The grits were not smooth at all and the etouffe had the biggest chunks of onions and peppers in it ever..they were bigger than the crawfish! My sister ordered the crab cake sandwich, i don't even know how to describe it bc it was nothing like any crab cake I'd ever tasted. All in all this seems to be one of those places that was great once upon a time but we won't be back.

Down right nasty. One of my biggest regrets in life is wasting my time and money by eating here. 

Very shocked at how many good reviews they have regarding the food.

Being from California, I always look forward to an opportunity to get some Soul or Cajun food when I'm in this part of the country so Boudreaux's seemed like a good choice.  While walking up to the restaurant the neighborhood reminded me of the funky shops and unique flavors found on Telegraph Avenue in Berkeley, CA.  Far from scaring me away, this was an endearing throw-back to home.  Across the street it was Hookah night  and the sweet tobacco scents drifted in the air.  As I shoved tightly folded dollars into the parking pay box ($3.00 which suprised me in an area so far from uptown) I noticed a fun looking book store on the back side of the restaurant. 

When my dining partner and I walked in we were seated quickly although the waiter seemed a little brusque (in fairness he did appear to be the only wait-staff that evening).  I finally settled on Ettouffee, Rice and of course corn bread.  I was suprised to find that the potent spices and flavors that usually accompany this dish seemed to be lacking.  The meal was fine, but a little bland for my preference and the cornbread was actually a little dry.

If you prefer milder Cajun cuisine, this might be the spot for you.  If you're looking for something more authentic... keep looking and let me know where you find it!
Had lunch, ordered tilapia and 2 sides with cornbread.  Service was good food was good.  The place looked clean, I would recommend to my friends.  The food was well seasoned, for my palate.

Half price bloody mary and mimosa bars on Sundays. Sold! 

I primarily come here for brunch (see line above), but I never order brunch-type food. She Crab Soup, Jambalya, Etouffee, Gumbo- give me all the Cajun goodness. My latest trip here though I did get a little brunch-y and got the low country shrimp and grits. Delicious. Our table of seven each got something different and all really enjoyed everything. The chicken and waffle sandwich is crazy! I love the giant pancake with the fried egg all in it. Must order for the table: the beignets. 

Back to the important things, this bloody mary bar- they have several different vodka infusions (habanero, rosemary garlic, cucumber basil). The spread on the bar itself is also impressive- homemade bloody mary mix, various squeeze bottles of juices (pickle, okra, olive), veggies. They do it right here. 

It's NoDa, so parking sucks. Be patient and look for a spot on a nearby street. Make sure to pay attention to all the parking signs and don't block anyone's driveway.
Pretty so so. Went from Yelp reviews. Food was just okay, not super hot. Service just okay. Ambience good.

Not a fan at all.  I was very surprised at the high ratings on this place since my experience was so disgusting. The pictures posted on yelp were NOT AT ALL like what we were served! I went here for dinner last night & should have known something was up due to the lack of people, especially when the other places in the area were slammed. I got the crawfish spinach dip & shrimp po boy. The chips were good for the spinach dip but the dip itself was lacking, and cold. My entree was basically lettuce on chewy bread, shrimp was minimal. My friend got the gumbo yaya and could only take a few bites before giving up. It looked like it had been dumped from a can and she said it tasted as if it had gone bad. Service was also lacking. Would never recommend this place!

Many friends suggested this place to us. Unfortunately I was not impressed. The gator bites were extremely small and tough. The BBQ shrimp were severely lacking in flavor. The fried chicken with the jambalaya was overcooked. Service was a bit slow as we waited 5 minutes to be greeted. The "garage door" was open and we had to smell exhaust fumes our entire meal. Overall the meal was decent... but unfortunately we won't be back.

I hate to give this place 1 star because most of the food is really good.  Today I stopped in for lunch and ordered fish and grits.  The waitress brought me shrimp and grits.  I told her and she said it would be 5 more minutes to correct it ( had already been there 30 minutes).  Another 20 minutes pass and she brings out food in to-go box and says she doesn't know why the cook put it in the box.  Now what am I supposed to do?  Eat it in the car?  I told her to forget it and left.  50 minutes for lunch and no food!  

On a side note, their cornbread needs work.  It's dry and bland.

I ordered the shrimp and grits and didn't realize they had spicy sausage with it. I was still going to pay for the meal but they insisted that I don't and gave me a free entree for my next visit.  They were very friendly and by far the best customer service I have ever received.
I absolutely love this place. It's one of my regulars. Some of the best food, not just Cajun food, in Charlotte. Period.

Bayou cooking has everything my little heart desires.  Seafood (especially that of the shelled variety), spice, and plenty of rice!  I never met a gumbo I didn't adore.  Truly.

Boudreax's is a nice break from the downtown Charlotte restaurant scene.  If you've never been to NoDa--you must check it out.  I haven't spent nearly enough time in this neck of the woods. I have eaten at Boudreax's twice for brunch.  Both times, I didn't leave disappointed.  However, I wasn't "wowed" the way I hoped I would be.

About 5 years ago, I went to Baton Rouge and had my first beignet.  My life hasn't been the same since.  The beignets at Boudreax's are nothing close to the crispy, sweet, drippy, fried dough ball dusted in powdered sugar I had in LA.  Instead, these were dry and bland. Described as "hot pockets with nothing in them" --the words didn't come out of my mouth.

Anyway, skip the beignets.  I do recommend the eggs benedict.  The cheddar cheese grits (extra $1) are AMAZING.  Yes.  Get those.  And the home fries are perfectly dark and just crispy enough.

The atmosphere is very laid back and warm.  There was live music when I was there which was a nice touch.  I prefer Cajun Queen to Boudreax's, but then again I have only dined in for brunch.
This place is phenomenal! Food, service and ambiance are all on point, can't wait to go back for more.
Excellent shrimp and grits. Zesty Cajun flavor with a lot of shrimp. Soft buttery cornbread on the side. The large size is an ample portion for dinner.

Shrimp and grits were the spiciest and good. Stay away from the spinach crawfish dip...has non point if view and very heavy. Gumbo was great. Cornbread was a perfect sweetness but was just a tad on the stale side. Waiter Caleb was perfect...ask for him.

What can I say...there needs to be more than 5 stars. These guys definitely out did themselves! They catered my dear friend's wedding reception which was for about 250 guests. I have to add that the bride is from Louisiana and all of her family came to SC for the wedding, so they were anxious to see how Boudreaux's compared to what they were used to. 

I was the contact for the reception, and was asked to coordinate the arrival and distribution of dinner. Once Kevin and Pete arrived, they wouldn't leave until everything was set in place and we were confident with what was in place. After my team and I served the approximately 250 guests, several of them came back for seconds and a few even came back for thirds. 

Everyone raved about how good dinner was. Even the Louisiana family absolutely loved it. The bride and groom were ecstatic!!! That's definitely a bonus!
The menu included: House salad w/ a variety of dressings and homemade croutons, Grilled Andouille Sausage, Blackened Chicken, Gumbo ya-ya, Jambalaya, Shrimp & Crawfish Étouffée & Fresh Grilled Veggies. 

We would definitely recommend this establishment to anyone and everyone. Whether it's for lunch or dinner at the restaurant or for catering an event. These guys know what they're doing and have the customer service and expertise to show it. Thanks again for helping make this the best day of the bride and grooms lives!

This was the worst.  Service was horrible.  Came in on a Wednesday night at 8:00 very few people in the restaurant.  Waitress acted like we bothering her by asking about items on the menu- which should be expected by new customers.  Hubby asked if there was anything on the menu with a white creamy Alfredo type sauce waitress said no.  He ordered something else and I ordered shrimp and grits.  I went to the bathroom and on the wall the special of the day was shrimp Alfredo?!?!  Hubby changed order to special.  

My hubby enjoyed the shrimp Alfredo though it was by no means the best he's ever had.  The shrimp and grits were GROSS.  How do you have grits that are not cheesy and half cooked to the point of crunchiness?!?!?  I have been to Louisiana and had Louisiana real quisine-and this was not it.

If you're gonna go, go for Sunday Brunch...if nothing else for the AMAZING Bloody Mary bar.

The food here is great. Muffuletta, po boys, shrimp and grits...

But, the service is just plain weird. Slow and socially awkward. If you can get past that, I'm sure you'll enjoy your meal.
Im eating their blackened wahoo BBQ right now and I never want it too end... for $14 this is sooo ridiculously good.
Had the pork chops here the other week. Really good stuff. Definitely more spices than other Cajun & Louisiana style restaurants in the area. Wife's shrimp and grits were great as well.
This place is great! We love going here for lunch! Their Cajun food is pretty authentic and so so delicious! They also have some great drink specials!

Came here on a Sunday night with my mom and sister for my Mom's birthday dinner. She loves seafood and Cajun dishes so I thought this place would be perfect since our usual belated shenanigans kept us from seafood connection. 

Got here around 8pm and it was completely empty. Our waiter was extremely chill but very friendly nonetheless. Took a minute to peruse the menus and everyone decided. I got the veggie burger with fries, my mom got the shrimp and grits and my sister, the chicken and waffle sandwich with fries. We ordered drinks afterwards and I got a brew from NoDa and my mom got the pineapple mango mojito. She enjoyed hers. The brew was a bit too hoppy for my taste but I managed to gulp down half. Not convinced it was a lager but hey, whatever. 

After about 30 minutes, our food arrived. My mom loved her entree sans her cornbread which she said was hard and dry. My whole plate was cold (veggie burger and fries) My sister had cold fries but devoured the chicken and waffles sandwich. The waiter brought new fries and on my Mom's suggestion I ended up trading in the veggie burger for a couple of sides: fries, grits and salad. The salad was magnificent and I wished I had just gotten a huge salad instead. The grits were well done too (which is saying a lot being that I'm a total grits snob). I also ordered the crawfish and spinach dip after the rest which was good but really needed some salt or seasoning. With copious amounts of salt it became delicious. 

All in all I would give them another shot earlier in the day but am a firm believer that if you're open, you should be able to deliver a five star experience (hence the 3 stars).

It's not the real thing but it's as close as you can get around here. I went for brunch and I want to go back and try dinner if I am around this area again. Their bloody mary hit the spot. Their beignets had a really good flavor though the dough was a little thick and the edges were crusty which was strange. They should have also been bigger but overall they were good. They claim to have crawfish etouffee which I want to try. I am skeptical of places that say they can cook that outside of LA unless its my house but I am willing to try it.

So, I have this weird thing I do: every time I go to a Cajun place I order shrimp and grits with the expectation that it will be somewhere between disappointing and catastrophically bad. Ordered same at Boudreaux's expecting same result.
Guess what: Best. Shrimp and grits. EVER.
As awesome as the staff is (and they are awesome), the food is more awesome by a magnitude of about 100.
I'll start looking for excuses to come back to Charlotte, and this will be the first stop.

Brunch is da bomb. Dinner is great. Lunch is intriguing. Have been here with at least 4 different groups of friends, and no one was disappointed. None of us could finish the more than ample portions, and the drinks/beer menu were good. This is a perennial favorite for eating anytime.

Our friends from Raleigh, NC were in town so we took them to NoDa in hopes of eating at other place for dinner. After finding out the wait time was 1 hour and a half, we decided to try another place and walked into Boudreaux's with low expectations. Boy were we pleasantly surprised!! We were sat immediately with no wait time. The place is very cool and the service was awesome. Our waitress knew that it was our first time and suggested the crawfish spinach dip and we were VERY glad that she did! Excellent! I had the salmon special and it was SO.GOOD! Food came out hot and fast. Hubby had some chicken fried something meal and it was oh sooooo good as well! We were defiantly glad that we stumbled upon this place and will def be back!

First time trying. The beignets were actually dinner rolls with sugar, the gumbo was slimey and the veggies in it were uncooked, red beans were full of fat and worst of all, we were handed a USED to-go container. Nice waitress but not coming back.
Both the Gator bites, and the gumbo are amazing; I have never been disappointed by the food.

I have been here for brunch a time or two.  The food is always good, I have never had a bad experience.  They have a bloody mary bar where you can put together your own bloody mary, which is one of my favorite drinks.  There are many toppings, sauces, and spices to choose from.  

The restaurant is small, but friendly. There is an option to sit outside.  The service is good and prompt.

This review is low due to the poor service we received. We went around 2pm there were not many people eating the place was not busy at all. Service was extremely slow. We ran out of tea waited 10 min before we were checked on for refills the we ran out again and a guy that said he was the manager was having a conversation with the table next to us for a long time. Meanwhile I was chomping on ice to get some liquid in my mouth. He as the manager should have been looking at the customers while he stood there talking and should have noticed we were being neglected. Then some other guy brought out the desert we ordered at the same time we ordered our meal. He just placed them on the table and walked away before I could ask for more tea. Finally our waitress that had cigarette stained teeth came back to ask if we wanted one check or two. I told here I needed a to go box for the desert and wanted more tea. I could not imagine choking down the desert without nothing to drink. She put the desert in a box and gave us the check and still no tea. BTW she reeked of smoke so I assume she was outside smoking instead of waiting on us.

Had brunch today. I ordered the shrimp and grits and was not disappointed. It was sooo good. The cornbread on the side could've easily not been there, but the dish itself was really good. I also tried the bloody mary bar. I'd never had one and the idea of selecting all of the ingredients was great. They were also half price today. My server was attentive and friendly and even helped me construct my drink with suggestions at the bar. There was also a sax player to boot lol. I'll be going back for more shrimp and grits.

Delicious! The She crab soup was so good and the Jambalaya was on point!  Pineapple mojito? Yes please!!  Waitress was super nice and service was fast. 

The restroom was a little dirty, and the corners looked like they needed a good sweeping. They do have a big garage door that they open in good weather so I'm sure that's the reason for the dust bunnies. Otherwise I would give 4 stars!

I've been to Bourdreaux before, long time ago. This most recent visit was great. I had shrimp and grits and my friend had the pork chops. It's the best feeling when food exceeds your expectations. The shrimp and grits did just that and I would argue that they're the best in Charlotte. It was apparent that the roux was fresh. The celery maintained crunch. My side of seafood gumbo was divine, but could use larger pieces of seafood.

Service:
My gumbo was served at the same time as the shrimp & grits, which wasn't ideal. Our waiter was kind and referred to us as "friends". As in substitute ma'am for friends. It was cute. The wait wasn't too long. When we were finished, we moved to the bar, having been in the restaurant for 2 hours. The bar tender was nice and VERY patient explaining different drinks. I ultimately had wine.

Needless to say this was a great outing and I will definitely return soon.

The food here is very flavorful. I had a party of 18 people here for my birthday and everyone loved their meals. I had the bourbon fried chicken and it was yummy! I also tried the pork chops on another occasion and the gumbo! It is in a cool area and the service is nice. The prices are pretty good as well.

A MUST to try in Charlotte's NODA district. LOVE LOVE LOVE this place...for breakfast, lunch, or dinner!  If you love New Orleans food then this is for you. The ambiance is great and the service is wonderful. The shrimp and grits my favorite!   I do not eat grits from anywhere except here, their cheese grits are the ultimate comfort food.

There is a lot of road work going on on 36th was hard to find for out off town ppl. The inside was very nice gold and purple colors with a live music the waiter Chip was pleasant. Do my fiancé got the gator bites very good tastes like chicken and I got the Cajun omelette not bad.

Great location for this Cajun eatery and bar. Cozy and spacious, if that makes sense....Get reservations if you have a large party, they will accommodate, but bring a flask because drink service is sloooooooowwww.

Food came out fast and hot which was nice for a large party like ours. The shrimp & grits was seasoned very well and pretty darn tasty. Not very spicy and slightly monotone in flavor, but not bad. They do well with their fish, as the blackened catfish was excellent. Lots of items to choose from; but kinda disappointed there were no buckets of crawdads to order. 

They make up for that with tons of specialty drinks, most were yummy and fruity for the ladies.

I would definitely try it again.

I LOOOOOOOVVVVVEEEEEEEEE jambalaya. 
Yea, I will drive up there just to buy 2 order to go and eat them during the week. (go figure)

Shrimp served without de-veining... Disgusting! We asked if they clean them up before serving but were told that they never clean them up. We used to be regulars here and they did the best seafood gumbo in town but we would rather not eat shrimp poop.

Okay, so I STILL haven't been to New Orleans yet so I can't really say how authentic a place is, but this is the second Cajun restaurant I've been to and it was so much better than the first one.

The service was excellent.  My waiter was very attentive and answered all my questions about the food and the drinks.  This is the first place I've been to that had an entire menu devoted to their Hurricanes.  Holy crap.  I can't remember which one I ultimately ordered, but it was excellent!  And strong!  I ended up getting the blackened catfish, which was great, but the best thing was the hashbrown casserole.  Hands down the best hashbrown casserole I've ever had in my life.  I was temped to ask if I could order a whole 'nother side of it on it's own.....

My wife and I love to stop in and grab a bowl of their delicious she crab soup with cornbread.  It is sooooo yummy!  I have tried almost every item on their menu and would recommend it all.  The staff is always friendly.  Great drink options also.  Got to stop in and check them out.

Delicious food that tastes like it was made by knowledgeable cajan chefs. They have some of the best cheese grits that I have tasted in a restaurant. The grits have an earthy taste that seem stone ground.  They have a unique texture. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive. The beignets are doughy and delicious. Best I've had as well.
Really great place. Came here before a show at the Neighbor Theatre. Outstanding food. Shrimp and Grits, killer. Pork chops were awesome. Come see.

I ate here about 2 weeks ago and the food was simply divine. It really does taste like something straight from New Orleans. I had the seafood gumbo (that comes with cornbread) and the alligator bites. The alligator bites are amazing, however, it might be the only overpriced thing on the menu ($10 appetizer). The seafood gumbo was dee-licious! For dessert, I had the bread pudding! AMAZING! I had a mimosa to drink with my meal. I was visiting from NJ and was extremely pleased with the food. The service was equally wonderful. I had a waitress named Stephanie who is an enabler haha! But I'm glad she convinced me to get the bread pudding. This place has good food, great service, and is priced right. Def check it out. You won't be disappointed!

I've never been to a Louisiana style restaurant so this was a no brainier for me. 

The menu based on their website had a very diverse selection of food that is also Louisiana style. I ordered the Shrimp & Grits which was different than I'm use to buy surprisingly it was tasty but soupy . I also ordered the Seafood Gumbo since I don't eat pork and all of their gumbo had sausage in it.  

I also ordered a Hurricane Category 3 which was very interesting. It's the typical hurricane but their spin on it is to add additional shots and increase the category so I was told a category 5 would put anyone on their butt. I ended up with the 3 which was made perfectly and tasty. I'll go back again to try a 4 and later a 5 .

Our Waiter Quan was very attentive, nice and welcoming so he received a great tip. He was very helpful in asking the bartender about the hurricane categories and also the kitchen on a few concerns about sausage not being included nor cross contamination with the shrimp.

I ended up spilling my drink (promise it wasn't bc of the category 3 lol) but Quan was very nice about cleaning up the spill and still provided amazing service. Thanks Quan for a great experience, I'll definitely be back to try a few things.

yes yes yum yum and I think my waiters name was Dave. Dave is A Ok

where do I start... ya ya gumbo .. fried chicken.... Zombie drink !!!

heaven

A great addition to NoDa and really something different from everything else in Charlotte.  Filling, delicious food at a great price.  They have some great drinks here in the morning and the afternoon with a decent patio for those sunny afternoons and cool summer nights plus they have a garage door open up the restaurant to the outside.

My family loves this restaurant! It is located in Charlotte's arts district, NoDa. Boudreaux's is a delicious restaurant serving an array of Cajun food. Their fries are delicious, and they also make a mean vegetarian jambalaya (but its a special, and sadly not always on the menu). I don't eat meat, but I've heard that if you want seafood in Charlotte this is one of the best places to go!

The staff is friendly and attentive. Order the strawberry beer!

Enjoyed Easter Brunch today at Boudreaux's.  The Bloody Mary bar was quite a deal at $4.00 per glass.  I ordred the Habanerno Vodka, complete with the warning from the waitress, who said, "be careful, it is hot!"  Well, after I loaded it with jalopeno pepper slices, horseradish and Texas Pete, it still exhibited only a warm friendliness.  I guess that was a disclaimer.  But, it was good, and a big glass with fixins' at $4.00 is a bargain.  I also asked for the 3 egg vegetarian omelet and Charleston Cheddar grits.  The grits were creamy and delicious!  The omelet could have used more cheese, but the spinach, mushrooms and red bell pepper were very flavorful.  The accompanying fruit was refreshing as well.  The restaurant featured a nice jazz duo, consisting of trumpet and guitar.  It was just loud enough to contribute to a nice atmosphere while still retaining the ability to have conversation.  In my opinion, Boudreaux's always provides both good, reliable food and ambiance, no matter the occasion.
Gator bites not worth $10.95 and a little plate came out. No taste identifiable. However i can vouch for the mango mojito

Pretty good food and a great environment. I ordered the collard greens, pasta salad, cornbread, and tilapia sticks. It was a lot of food for a good price. My meal was about $9. The tilapia was so fresh! The only thing I didn't like was the collard greens... Too sweet. 

This place looks like a hole in the wall but the food makes up for it. Bathrooms are also in an awkward spot so prepared to look stupid. Parking sucks due to all the construction- I came here during lunch with coworkers and can only imagine what the parking is like at night.

2.5 stars for Bourdreaux's. I was really excited to try cajun/creole food while visiting Charlotte, but was not that impressed by the dishes we ordered here. Our waiter was really nice and checked up on us often

The two of us decided on the jambalaya and shrimp po' boy to share:

Jambalaya- Came with a good amount of meat and seafood! but TOO SALTY. The side of cornbread was also forgettable. Dry and just whatevs. 

Shrimp po boy- I liked this sandwich overall, but it just seemed like a regular fried shrimp sub. The bread was actually very fresh, and the shrimp pieces weren't small or skimpy.
The FRIES though were really CRISPY and seasoned well! My favorite part of the meal for sure. I would come back just for the fries.

This was actually a lot of food for the both of us! and we left pretty stuffed
Not sure I'd make my way back here though :/

Tried this place for lunch, arrived there at 2 pm and we ordered right away. My friends got their entres from the breakfast menu, I ordered the PO boy sandwich. The ordered took 50 min to reach the table, the sandwich was very bland and tasteless barely any sauce on there! I ordered the Mac and cheese as a side, which has ham in it. The menu fails to mention anywhere on it that it has any sort of meats in it. Being a pescatarian, it's surely not something I would like. The waitress was nice to address bringing out another side but at that point I was just done. It's a nice place to hang out, however the service needs to be worked on and the food look more appetizing and better flavored.

I have been coming here for awhile, and truth be told, the quality is getting worse.
1st tip: DO NOT EVEN BOTHER with the fried oysters. You will hate yourself for ordering that. The oysters are so tiny, and it's not worth the money. Actually put the gator bites on the do-not-order list as well. They're smaller than the popcorn chicken you get at KFC. 
I normally come here and order the gumbo or she crab soup and make that a meal. A bowl runs you about $8-9, which is a lot more tolerable. Sometimes the gumbo comes out luke warm (at best), but it tastes good enough.
If anything, consider this place for a drink, they do have drink specials on the hurricanes and wine and beer. 
I really hate that one of the few cajun places in Charlotte is going downhill.

Nice atmosphere. We went on a Monday night and were the only ones in the restaurant. I don't know if the fact that their liquor license is pending is the reason it was so empty. 

But overall I was very satisfied, I got the seafood gumbo and my date got the shrimp and grits.  The food was pretty good, although it wasn't as spicy as i like my Louisiana cuisine it was still good. 

There aren't too many authentic Louisiana food places in Charlotte so this was a great find.  It also doesn't hurt that its located in my favorite part of town (NoDa). 

Go check it out.

Date night with Mrs. K., we headed to NoDa of course!

On a Saturday night, there was a solid wait for a table - 45 minutes. We spent it wandering the nearby neighborhood and were only accosted by one "upper class" beggar who wanted "a dollar toward a vegetarian burrito, man". Love NoDa!

We started with the "Gator Bites" - a small plate of battered and fried alligator tail. Despite living in South Florida for a decade, I've somehow managed to miss out on this delicacy. Tender and rather buttery, you should give it a try.

For our mains, I chose the day's special - a half-rack of St. Louis Ribs which came with an ear of corn and cole slaw and fries. I cleaned the plate. I love ribs and these were particularly fall-off-the-bone. My date chose the blackened steak, which she said was cooked perfectly and the side greens were excellent.

I would have thought that after a meal like this we would have been stuffed solid, but our lovely waitress managed to convince us to share a bread pudding and cappuccino.

Great meal, great service, great date. We will absolutely be back!

When I am in the area this is one of the top places on the list!  Best shrimp and grits and jambalaya I have ever had to date.  
Service is always prompt and casual. Interested to see how it changes as Noda does, they have recently updated the place and it looks great. I am looking forward to the new menu. 
Large portions also at affordable prices!  You won't be disappointed.
Great place for some creole food in Noda, enjoyed the gator bites and po boy, nice outdoor seating as well and great dessert. Service is slow however and not top notch.
Great food, music, service, and art work! I'm definitely making this a regular hangout spot. Oh! Did I mention they have tv's for sports? Awesome!!!
Craving New Orleans? Come here! Great food and probably the best French fries you will ever have!

Oh Boudreax's, how i love you..

Whenever I visit my sister in Charlotte, we go here..her family actually has taken me, my mom and brother all there..on  separate occasions..were all fans!

This time i had brought my little dog with me on my first road trip and he got to go some pretty great places..the server brought a water bowl out for him when he brought our drinks :)

We had the gator bites appetizer that is really good and my nephew LOVES them..for my entree i always choose the Low Country Shrimp and Grits..creamy cheese grits with plump shrimp and sausage with veggies and all in a great sauce served with a square of some of the best cornbread in this world! 

you will leave stuffed, happy and with some left overs too!

Love what we ordered here. The chicken is crispy outside and tender inside. The etouffee is fantastic as well!!! Will return to try other dishes on menu!

2nd time we came here on a Saturday for brunch. We ordered beignet (each order comes with 3), and Crawfish Spinach Dips as appetizers. Both appetizers are pretty good! Entrees wise: Chicken Waffle (not the type I like though, the chicken lost its crispyness once mixed with cheese, etc), Cajun Chicken Omelet (it's not bad but not great), Burbank Chicken (again, our favorite one so far besides etouffee.

I served tables for several years of my life and always tip 20% or higher. Last night I had to leave 10% because I just couldn't bring myself to reward our experience. We had a party of 12 people and we were there for 3 hours due to how long things took to get ordered, come out, etc. While I understand parties take longer, it's a Friday night, etc....the lack of attention and inaccuracies by the server were unacceptable.  People were getting new alcoholic drinks when they didn't even order them, but when they were ordered it would take 20 minutes to arrive....want a beer?  How about the wrong one?  To the wrong person...food came out and the temperature ranged from piping hot to downright cold. How you do this with the same entree is downright impressive, btw!  The bills came out...wrong. It was just ridiculous. Only thing that saves this from a 1 star is the crawfish and spinach appetizer was awesome and some of the entrees were decent (and not cold).  It'll be a struggle to return here.
Food was good, but disappointing. The roux wasn't cooked down, it seemed fluffy and floury instead of a gravy.

If you are ever in the mood for Louisiana style creole food ..... than this is the place to go! They have a variety of things to choose from and best of all a great brunch menu. Definitely a thumbs up!

I went with a group of five to have Sunday dinner prior to catching James Lastra performing at the Evening Muse which is just across the street.

They have nice selection of cajun/creole on the menu. I had the shrimp and crawfish etoufee. It was good, but I didn't care for abundance of uncooked celery.

Everyone liked what they had and we all shared some of the She Crab soup for an appetizer, it was really good.

The service was fair, even though it was slow for a Sun evening.

I'm not huge fan of spicy foods so my review may be tainted; however, I can say the food I have tried here is some of the best Cajun food I found in Charlotte. Whenever I have out-of-town guests coming who have also lived in Louisiana, this is always one of our spots to stop in. Their menu features dishes that are definitely in line with traditional Cajun cuisine, which is nice because you know you're getting the true Cajun experience.

And with the addition of gator bites, there's always something on the menu that I'm sure you'll be trying for the first time.
